docs.lead_paragraph: The evidence that a simple blood test can predict a patient's risk of heart disease has been increasing over the years. But a large study published last week raises questions about the test's usefulness. British researchers have found that routine testing for C-reactive protein, a substance that signals the presence of inflammation in blood vessels, is not as reliable an indicator of cardiovascular problems as factors like high cholesterol, obesity and smoking.

headline.main: Heart Study Challenges Protein's Predictive Power

docs.abstract: C-reactive protein, substance that has been identified as marker for heart disease, may not be as reliable as earlier thought; Dr John Danesh, Cambridge University epidemiologist and lead author of recent study on C-reactive protein, finds that measuring established cardiovascular risk factors is as effective as testing CRP levels; critics hold that study guidelines diluted results; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and American Heart Assn both suggest use of CRP screening for people at moderate risk of heart disease (M)
docs.snippet: The evidence that a simple blood test can predict a patient's risk of heart disease has been increasing over the years. But a large study published last week raises questions about the test's usefulness.    British researchers have found that routine...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, public health advocates have championed harm reduction for people who cannot stop taking health risks -- or do not want to. Needle exchange is a classic example. Intravenous drug users get clean needles because, the reasoning goes, contracting and spreading AIDS is worse than making heroin use a little easier. But harm reduction for hard-core smokers is another matter.
docs.abstract: Dr Sally Satel, American Enterprise Institute resident scholar and psychiatrist, holds that snus, smokeless alternative to cigarettes widely used in Sweden, is viable option for smoker who cannot quit; harm reduction strategies to deal with public health concerns discussed; information given by Health and Human Services Department and Surgeon General Dr Richard H Carmona conflicts with recent studies that show snus is safer than smoking and does not increase risk of oral cancer (M)
docs.snippet: For decades, public health advocates have championed harm reduction for people who cannot stop taking health risks -- or do not want to. Needle exchange is a classic example. Intravenous drug users get clean needles because, the reasoning goes,...

docs.lead_paragraph: The patient was led reluctantly into my office by his girlfriend. Over the course of the past month, she explained, Adam had become uncharacteristically nervous and snappish. He hardly slept, and when he did she noticed that his muscles twitched.

headline.main: Jittery? Peevish? Can't Sleep? What Are You Drinking?

docs.abstract: Cases article describes potent effects of too much caffeine on physical and mental well-being; tells of college student consuming abnormally large amounts of coffee to keep up with academic work who becomes anxious, twitchy, and unable to sleep; caffeine is most widely used stimulant in world; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The patient was led reluctantly into my office by his girlfriend.    Over the course of the past month, she explained, Adam had become uncharacteristically nervous and snappish. He hardly slept, and when he did she noticed that his muscles twitched.

docs.lead_paragraph: A drug prescribed to prevent premature births may leave children's brains especially vulnerable to the damaging effects of environmental pollutants, a study of the drug in rats suggests. Researchers from Duke, writing in last month's Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology, said the finding might explain why some children whose mothers were given the drug, terbutaline, had been shown to be at higher risk for learning and behavioral problems.
docs.abstract: Terbutaline, drug given to women who are at risk of giving birth prematurely, is thought to pose risk to child that may lead to learning and behavioral problems later in life; Duke University researchers, writing in Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology, describe negative effects of drug on rats; American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists holds that premature birth is leading cause of infant death and major cause of illness (S)
docs.snippet: A drug prescribed to prevent premature births may leave children's brains especially vulnerable to the damaging effects of environmental pollutants, a study of the drug in rats suggests.    Researchers from Duke, writing in last month's Toxicology...

docs.lead_paragraph: With a stylish exterior of metallic blue and gray, the device looks like a personal digital assistant but slightly larger. Julius Mendalis, 84, a lawyer for the company that makes Arizona Iced Tea, paid $795 for this gadget, and he loves it, though he is not a man of technology, rarely uses computers and does not surf the Web.

headline.main: Sleek New Devices Help Low-Vision Patients See

docs.abstract: Estimated 16 million Americans suffer from uncorrectable vision problems often caused by serious eye diseases like cataracts, glaucoma or macular degeneration; recent study of low-vision patients conducted by Lighthouse International finds that people who use optical aids have considerably less depression than those using adaptive aids, like large-print books and talking clocks; Quicklook, optical aid, is hand-held device that acts as electronic magnifying glass and enables patient to read independently; other optical aids described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: With a stylish exterior of metallic blue and gray, the device looks like a personal digital assistant but slightly larger.    Julius Mendalis, 84, a lawyer for the company that makes Arizona Iced Tea, paid $795 for this gadget, and he loves it,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans are more likely to be overweight than the Chinese, and extra pounds are associated with a higher risk of arthritis of the knee. But elderly Chinese men and women are more likely than older Americans to suffer from the disorder, perhaps because of the common practice of squatting.
docs.abstract: Dr Yuqing Zhang of Boston University leads research that shows elderly Chinese men and women are more likely to develop arthritis of knee than American seniors; study, which appears in Arthritis & Rheumatism journal, suggests that key factor is amount of extended squatting during earlier period in life (S)
docs.snippet: Americans are more likely to be overweight than the Chinese, and extra pounds are associated with a higher risk of arthritis of the knee.    But elderly Chinese men and women are more likely than older Americans to suffer from the disorder, perhaps...

docs.lead_paragraph: Four organizations with an interest in international health announced yesterday that they would join forces to help more than 100 countries get inexpensive generic AIDS drugs and discounted AIDS tests. If they succeed, generic drugs made by Indian and South African companies could reach virtually every poor country at prices as low as $140 per patient per year.

headline.main: Plan to Bring Generic AIDS Drugs to Poor Nations

docs.abstract: William J Clinton Presidential Foundation, Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, World Bank and Unicef announce plan to join forces in order to provide low-cost generic AIDS drugs to more than 100 countries; large-scale plan does not have official approval of suppliers, which have only recently implemented price-reduction programs for certain nations under agreement with Clinton Foundation; drug suppliers include Aspen Pharmacare of South Africa and Indian companies Cipla Ltd, Ranbaxy Laboratories Ltd, Hetero Drugs Ltd and Matrix Pharmaceutical Inc; World Health Organization has approved generic drugs made by these manufacturers; Bush administration has shown unwillingness to allow purchase of generic drugs to fight global AIDS crisis; conditions countries must meet to qualify for lower priced drugs discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Four organizations with an interest in international health announced yesterday that they would join forces to help more than 100 countries get inexpensive generic AIDS drugs and discounted AIDS tests.    If they succeed, generic drugs made by Indian...

keywords.value: GLOBAL FUND TO FIGHT AIDS, TUBERCULOSIS AND MALARIA

docs.lead_paragraph: Last month, 25,000 medical students held their breath and peeled open white envelopes to learn where they would spend the next three to seven years of their lives. For more than half a century, the match, as the process of pairing graduating medical students with residency programs is called, has been a rite of passage. A computer does the matching. The results, announced at noon Eastern time on the third Thursday in March, control where the best and the worst doctors are headed and shape health care for millions of Americans.

headline.main: A Job or More School? Young Doctors Take On 'the Match'

docs.abstract: Medical school graduates participate in process that pairs them with residency programs called the match; residency, which provides valuable hands on experience for graduates, requires longer hours and pays much less than staff physicians earn; match process and possible reforms discussed; nationally, average intern earns slightly less than $40,000 per year; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Last month, 25,000 medical students held their breath and peeled open white envelopes to learn where they would spend the next three to seven years of their lives.    For more than half a century, the match, as the process of pairing graduating...

byline.original: By ALEXI WRIGHT and INGRID KATZ

docs.lead_paragraph: Emergency workers sometimes lower the chances that heart attack victims will survive by improperly administering CPR, researchers reported yesterday. The study, published in the journal Circulation, found that some paramedics were giving too many breaths a minute in performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The researchers, led by Dr. Tom P. Aufderheide of the Medical College of Wisconsin, observed paramedics in Milwaukee giving CPR to heart attack patients.

headline.main: When CPR Takes a Deadly Turn

docs.abstract: Dr Tom P Aufderheide of Medical College of Wisconsin leads research published in journal Circulation that finds emergency workers may not be performing CPR correctly; American Heart Assn recommends administering 12 to 15 breaths per minute when giving CPR and parametics observed in study gave about 37 breaths per minute; researchers suggest that too much ventilation may make it more difficult for blood to return to heart; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Emergency workers sometimes lower the chances that heart attack victims will survive by improperly administering CPR, researchers reported yesterday.     The study, published in the journal Circulation, found that some paramedics were giving too many...

docs.lead_paragraph: Physicians call it shingles, from the Latin word cingulum, meaning belt or girdle. Scientists call the virus that causes the disease varicella-zoster -- varicella the Latin word for little pox, zoster the Greek word for girdle. The Italians refer to shingles as St. Anthony's fire. And some sufferers call its occasional aftermath -- postherpetic neuralgia -- pure and simple torture, the worst pain imaginable, 10 times as bad as giving birth and excruciating enough to drive a person to suicide.

headline.main: Return of the Chickenpox, Uglier and Meaner

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses painful ailment shingles and its origins in chickenpox; one in five Americans living to 75 years of age will develop shingles, which can be triggered by stress or weakened immune system; shingles is best controlled through agressive antiviral treatment within 72 hours of onset of symptoms, but can be hard to diagnose because symptons are vague in nature; drawing (M)
